# Shot Heard 'Round the World (baseball)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/6/6c/Thomson_19511003.JPG)](/wiki/File:Thomson_19511003.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Thomson_19511003.JPG "Enlarge")

The Shot Heard 'Round the World: Dotted line represents the approximate track
of Thomson's game-winning line drive home run

In [baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball"), the "**Shot Heard 'Round the
World**" was a game-winning [home run](/wiki/Home_run "Home run") by [New York
Giants](/wiki/1951_New_York_Giants_\(MLB\)_season "1951 New York Giants
\(MLB\) season") [outfielder](/wiki/Outfielder "Outfielder") and [third
baseman](/wiki/Third_baseman "Third baseman") [Bobby
Thomson](/wiki/Bobby_Thomson "Bobby Thomson") off [Brooklyn
Dodgers](/wiki/1951_Brooklyn_Dodgers_season "1951 Brooklyn Dodgers season")
[pitcher](/wiki/Pitcher "Pitcher") [Ralph Branca](/wiki/Ralph_Branca "Ralph
Branca") at the [Polo Grounds](/wiki/Polo_Grounds "Polo Grounds") in New York
City on October 3, 1951, to win the [National League](/wiki/National_League
"National League") (NL) [pennant](/wiki/Pennant_\(sports\) "Pennant
\(sports\)"). Thomson's dramatic three-run homer came in the ninth inning of
the decisive third game of a [three-game playoff for the
pennant](/wiki/1951_National_League_tie-breaker_series "1951 National League
tie-breaker series") in which the Giants trailed, 4–2.[1]

The game—the first ever televised nationally—was seen by millions of viewers
across America and heard on radio by millions more, including thousands of
American servicemen stationed in [Korea](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War"),
listening on [Armed Forces Radio](/wiki/Armed_Forces_Radio "Armed Forces
Radio"). The classic drama of snatching victory from defeat to secure a
pennant was intensified by the epic [cross-town
rivalry](/wiki/Dodgers%E2%80%93Giants_rivalry "Dodgers–Giants rivalry")
between the Giants and Dodgers, and by a remarkable string of victories in the
last weeks of the regular season by the Giants, who won 37 of their last 44
games to catch the first-place Dodgers and force a playoff series to decide
the NL champion. The Giants' late-season rally and 2-to-1-game playoff
victory, capped by Thomson's moment of triumph, are collectively known in
baseball lore as "The Miracle of [Coogan's Bluff](/wiki/Coogan%27s_Bluff
"Coogan's Bluff")", a descriptor coined by the legendary sports columnist [Red
Smith](/wiki/Red_Smith_\(sportswriter\) "Red Smith \(sportswriter\)").[2]

The phrase "[shot heard 'round the world](/wiki/Shot_heard_%27round_the_world
"Shot heard 'round the world")" is from the poem "[Concord
Hymn](/wiki/Concord_Hymn "Concord Hymn")" (1837) by [Ralph Waldo
Emerson](/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson "Ralph Waldo Emerson") about the first
clash of the [American Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War
"American Revolutionary War"). It later became popularly associated with
Thomson's homer and several other dramatic historical moments.[3]

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

The principal [National League](/wiki/National_League "National League") (NL)
contenders in [1951](/wiki/1951_Major_League_Baseball_season "1951 Major
League Baseball season") were the [New York
Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants_\(NL\) "New York Giants \(NL\)"), [Brooklyn
Dodgers](/wiki/Brooklyn_Dodgers "Brooklyn Dodgers"), and [Philadelphia
Phillies](/wiki/Philadelphia_Phillies "Philadelphia Phillies"). The Dodgers
quickly pulled into first place, and widened their lead as the season
progressed. On August 11, with a  13 1⁄2-game lead over the second-place
Giants, they appeared certain to face the [New York
Yankees](/wiki/New_York_Yankees "New York Yankees") in the [World
Series](/wiki/1951_World_Series "1951 World Series").[4] "Unless [the Dodgers]
completely fold in their last 50 games", wrote an Associated Press writer,
"they're in."[5] The Phillies,  14 1⁄2 [games back](/wiki/Games_back "Games
back"), faded from contention; but the Giants won 16 straight games from
August 12 to August 27, cutting the Dodgers' lead to six games.[6] By
September 20, they had pulled to within  4 1⁄2 games,[7] still a prohibitive
margin with only ten days remaining in the season; but the Giants won all of
their final seven games, while the Dodgers lost six of their last ten. The two
teams concluded the regular season deadlocked with 96–58 records.[8]

The NL used a three-game playoff at that time to break ties for the
[pennant](/wiki/Pennant_\(sports\) "Pennant \(sports\)"). The Dodgers won the
coin toss to determine the playoff schedule; they elected to play the first
game at home and the second (and third if needed) at the Polo Grounds,
reasoning that after a likely win in Brooklyn, they would need to win only one
of two at the Giants' park.[9] Nevertheless, in game one at [Ebbets
Field](/wiki/Ebbets_Field "Ebbets Field"), the Giants, with [Jim
Hearn](/wiki/Jim_Hearn "Jim Hearn") on the mound, defeated the Dodgers' [Ralph
Branca](/wiki/Ralph_Branca "Ralph Branca") 3–1,[10] thanks to [home
runs](/wiki/Home_run "Home run") by [Bobby Thomson](/wiki/Bobby_Thomson "Bobby
Thomson") and [Monte Irvin](/wiki/Monte_Irvin "Monte Irvin").[11] In game two
at the Polo Grounds, with the Yankees team in attendance as spectators,[12]
the Dodgers tied the series, winning 10–0 on home runs by [Jackie
Robinson](/wiki/Jackie_Robinson "Jackie Robinson"), [Gil
Hodges](/wiki/Gil_Hodges "Gil Hodges"), [Andy Pafko](/wiki/Andy_Pafko "Andy
Pafko"), and [Rube Walker](/wiki/Rube_Walker "Rube Walker"), who was catching
in place of an injured [Roy Campanella](/wiki/Roy_Campanella "Roy
Campanella"). [Clem Labine](/wiki/Clem_Labine "Clem Labine") pitched a six-hit
shutout against [Sheldon Jones](/wiki/Sheldon_Jones "Sheldon Jones").[13][14]
The 1–1 deadlock set up the deciding third game at the Polo Grounds on October
3.

## The
game[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: The game")]

Team | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | 7 | 8 | 9 | [R](/wiki/Run_\(baseball\) "Run \(baseball\)") | [H](/wiki/Hit_\(baseball\) "Hit \(baseball\)") | [E](/wiki/Error_\(baseball\) "Error \(baseball\)")  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
Brooklyn | 1 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 3 | 0 | 4 | 8 | 0  
**New York** | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 4 | 5 | 8 | 0  
**[WP](/wiki/Win%E2%80%93loss_record_\(pitching\)#Winning_pitcher "Win–loss
record \(pitching\)"):** [Larry Jansen](/wiki/Larry_Jansen "Larry Jansen")
(23–11) **[LP](/wiki/Win%E2%80%93loss_record_\(pitching\)#Losing_pitcher
"Win–loss record \(pitching\)"):** [Ralph Branca](/wiki/Ralph_Branca "Ralph
Branca") (13–12)  
**[Home runs](/wiki/Home_run "Home run"):**  
BKN: None  
NYG: [Bobby Thomson](/wiki/Bobby_Thomson "Bobby Thomson") (32)  
  
For game three, [Sal Maglie](/wiki/Sal_Maglie "Sal Maglie") was on the mound
for New York, while Brooklyn called on [Don Newcombe](/wiki/Don_Newcombe "Don
Newcombe").[15] In the first inning, Robinson singled in [Pee Wee
Reese](/wiki/Pee_Wee_Reese "Pee Wee Reese") for the game's first run. A Giants
rally in the second inning, initiated by [Whitey Lockman](/wiki/Whitey_Lockman
"Whitey Lockman")'s single, fizzled when Thomson, trying to stretch a single
into a double, failed to notice that Lockman had not advanced to third base,
and was tagged out by Robinson.[2] The score remained 1–0 through the sixth
inning.[16] In the seventh inning, Irvin led off with a double for the Giants.
He was bunted over to third, and scored on a [sacrifice
fly](/wiki/Sacrifice_fly "Sacrifice fly") by Thomson, tying the score at one
run each.[16]

In the top of the eighth, the Dodgers came back with three runs. With Reese
and [Duke Snider](/wiki/Duke_Snider "Duke Snider") on third and first after
back-to-back singles, a Maglie [wild pitch](/wiki/Wild_pitch "Wild pitch")
allowed Reese to score and Snider to advance to second. Robinson was walked
intentionally to set up a double play, but Pafko's ground ball to third
bounced off the heel of Thomson's glove; Snider scored and Robinson took
third. [Billy Cox](/wiki/Billy_Cox_\(baseball\) "Billy Cox \(baseball\)")
added another single to score Robinson, making the score 4–1 in favor of the
Dodgers.[16] Newcombe set down the Giants in order in the bottom of the
eighth, while [Larry Jansen](/wiki/Larry_Jansen "Larry Jansen") did the same
in relief of Maglie in the top of the ninth.[17]

Newcombe had pitched a complete game on September 29, four days earlier, in
Philadelphia, followed by 5⅔ innings in relief the following day during the
last game of the regular season. According to some accounts, after eight
innings on only two days' rest he attempted to take himself out of the game,
but Robinson demanded that he continue: "You go out there and pitch until your
arm falls off!" Newcombe himself insisted that he never asked to be relieved—a
version corroborated by Snider and Pafko.[18]

Giants shortstop [Alvin Dark](/wiki/Alvin_Dark "Alvin Dark") singled off
Newcombe to start the bottom-ninth rally. At that point, the Dodgers made a
crucial defensive mistake: With no outs, a runner on first, and a 3-run lead,
the normal strategy would be to position the infield for a possible double
play; but first baseman [Gil Hodges](/wiki/Gil_Hodges "Gil Hodges") played
behind Dark—apparently guarding against a highly unlikely steal
attempt—leaving a large gap on the right side of the infield.[9] [Don
Mueller](/wiki/Don_Mueller "Don Mueller"), batting left-handed, hit a single
through that gap, advancing Dark from first to third. Instead of a rally-
killing double play, the Dodgers found themselves facing the potential tying
run at the plate with two runners on base, nobody out, and Irvin—with 121
regular-season RBIs—at bat; but Newcombe got Irvin to chase an outside pitch
and foul out to Hodges.[9] (Sportswriter [Bud Greenspan](/wiki/Bud_Greenspan
"Bud Greenspan") and others have argued that, had the Dodger infield played
Mueller at double-play depth, Irvin's pop-up would in all likelihood have been
the season-ending third out.[19])

Lockman followed with a double down the left field line, driving in Dark and
advancing Mueller to third. Mueller slid awkwardly into the base, injuring his
ankle, and was replaced by pinch runner [Clint Hartung](/wiki/Clint_Hartung
"Clint Hartung").[9] With Thomson coming up, Dodgers manager [Chuck
Dressen](/wiki/Chuck_Dressen "Chuck Dressen") finally pulled the exhausted
Newcombe. In the bullpen, where Branca and [Carl Erskine](/wiki/Carl_Erskine
"Carl Erskine") were warming up, coach [Clyde Sukeforth](/wiki/Clyde_Sukeforth
"Clyde Sukeforth") noticed that Erskine—who had been troubled by arm problems
all season—was bouncing his curve balls short of the plate, and advised
Dressen to use Branca in relief. That decision has been continually second-
guessed by fans, sportswriters, and baseball historians: Branca had lost six
of his last seven decisions, and gave up a game-winning home run to Thomson in
the first playoff game. Dressen's options, however, were severely limited: the
only other available pitchers with crucial-situation experience were [Clyde
King](/wiki/Clyde_King "Clyde King"), who was sidelined with biceps
tendonitis; [Preacher Roe](/wiki/Preacher_Roe "Preacher Roe"), who was left-
handed; and Labine, who had pitched a complete game the day before. This was
the second questionable decision that inning by Dressen.[20]

Thomson was now at bat, with first base open and [Willie
Mays](/wiki/Willie_Mays "Willie Mays") (soon to be named the NL [Rookie of the
Year](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_Rookie_of_the_Year_Award "Major League
Baseball Rookie of the Year Award")) on deck. Mays had gone 0-for-3 with two
strikeouts against Branca in the first playoff game, but Dressen was unwilling
to put the winning run on base, and worried that a veteran pinch hitter might
be brought in to bat for Mays if he did so.[9] In the third controversial
decision, he elected to pitch to Thomson rather than walk him
intentionally.[21] Thomson later recalled that as he left the on-deck circle,
Giants manager [Leo Durocher](/wiki/Leo_Durocher "Leo Durocher") turned to him
and said, "If you ever hit one, hit it now."[22]

Branca's first pitch was a called strike on the inside corner. His second was
a fastball high and inside, intended as a setup for his next, a breaking ball
down and away; but Thomson pulled the fastball down the left field line. The
ball disappeared into the lower-deck stands near the left field foul line for
a game-ending, three-run home run. Thomson ran the bases, then disappeared
into a mob of jubilant teammates gathered at home plate. The stunned Dodger
players began the long walk toward the visitors' clubhouse under the center
field bleachers; Robinson turned to watch Thomson, making certain that he
touched every base, before following his teammates off the field.[9]

Later, after the celebrations had calmed down, a delegation of Dodgers—Reese,
Snider, Roe, and Robinson—visited the Giants' locker room to offer their
congratulations. "I just want you to know that we didn't lose the pennant,"
Robinson told them. "You guys won it."[9]

## The
broadcasts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: The broadcasts")]

Several television and radio broadcasters captured the moment for baseball
fans in the New York City area and nationwide.[23]

### Russ
Hodges[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Russ Hodges")]

The best known live description—"arguably the most famous call in
sports"[24]—was delivered by [Russ Hodges](/wiki/Russ_Hodges "Russ Hodges"),
who was broadcasting the game on [WMCA-AM](/wiki/WMCA_\(AM\) "WMCA \(AM\)")
radio for Giants fans. His call captured the suddenness and exultation of the
home run:

“ | There's a long drive ... it's gonna be, I believe ... _The Giants win the pennant! The Giants win the pennant! The Giants win the pennant! The Giants win the pennant!_ Bobby Thomson hits into the lower deck of the left-field stands! The Giants win the pennant and they're going crazy! They're going crazy! I don't believe it! I don't believe it! I do not believe it! Bobby Thomson hit a line drive into the lower deck of the left-field stands and this blame place is going crazy! The Giants! [Horace Stoneham](/wiki/Horace_Stoneham "Horace Stoneham") has got a winner! The Giants won it by a score of 5 to 4, and they're picking Bobby Thomson up, and carrying him off the field![25] | ”  
---|---|---  
  
Broadcasts were not routinely taped in 1951, and no one at any of the local
radio or television stations was recording the game. The WMCA call survives
only because a Brooklyn-based fan named Lawrence Goldberg asked his mother to
tape-record the last half-inning of the radio broadcast while he was at
work.[26] In later years, Hodges told interviewers that Goldberg was a Dodgers
fan who made the tape "so he could hear the voice of the Giants weep when
Brooklyn won". In fact, Goldberg had been a Giants fan since
childhood.[26][27]

### Ernie
Harwell[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Ernie Harwell")]

Hodges' broadcast partner, [Ernie Harwell](/wiki/Ernie_Harwell "Ernie
Harwell"), called the game for the Giants' television flagship
[WPIX](/wiki/WPIX "WPIX"); the independent station's broadcast was carried
nationally on the [NBC](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_on_NBC "Major League
Baseball on NBC") network, the first coast-to-coast live telecast of a Major
League Baseball game. His description was not recorded; he later recalled
saying simply, "It's gone!" almost at the moment Thomson's bat struck the
ball—and then watching in dismay as the ball began to sink. "I said to myself,
'If that ball drops into Pafko's glove, I'm in deep trouble.' "[9] As the ball
disappeared into the lower deck, he recalled, no further commentary was
necessary. "The pictures took over."[28]

### Red
Barber[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Red Barber")]

Dodgers announcer [Red Barber](/wiki/Red_Barber "Red Barber"), calling the
game for [WMGM-AM](/wiki/WEPN_\(AM\) "WEPN \(AM\)") radio, straightforwardly
said, "Branca pumps, delivers – a curve, swung on and belted, deep shot to
left field—it is—a home run! And the New York Giants win the National League
pennant and the Polo Grounds goes wild!" Barber was openly critical of Hodges'
famous call, labeling it "unprofessional".[24]

### Gordon
McLendon[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Gordon McLendon")]

Only local Giants fans heard the famous Hodges call live. Most listeners heard
[Gordon McLendon](/wiki/Gordon_McLendon "Gordon McLendon")'s call on the
[Liberty Broadcasting System](/wiki/Liberty_Broadcasting_System "Liberty
Broadcasting System"), which carried the game nationally. McLendon's account
(complete with a similarly enthusiastic yell of "_The Giants win the pennant!
"_)—preserved on Harwell's "Audio Scrapbook"—remains the only professionally
recorded broadcast account of the entire third game.[29]

###
Other[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other")]

The game was also called on radio by [Al Helfer](/wiki/Al_Helfer "Al Helfer")
for the [Mutual](/wiki/Major_League_Baseball_on_Mutual "Major League Baseball
on Mutual") network, by [Buck Canel](/wiki/Buck_Canel "Buck Canel") and [Felo
Ramírez](/wiki/Felo_Ram%C3%ADrez "Felo Ramírez") for a [Spanish
language](/wiki/Spanish_language "Spanish language") network, and by [Nat
Allbright](/wiki/Nat_Allbright "Nat Allbright") in a studio re-creation for
the Dodgers' secondary network in the South. [Harry Caray](/wiki/Harry_Caray
"Harry Caray"), who had called [St. Louis
Cardinals](/wiki/1951_St._Louis_Cardinals_season "1951 St. Louis Cardinals
season") games during the season, was in the WMCA booth with Hodges and may
have also participated in broadcasting the game.[30][31]

##
Aftermath[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Aftermath")]

On October 4, the _[New York Daily News](/wiki/New_York_Daily_News "New York
Daily News")_ ran a front-page game recap under the headline, _" The Shot
Heard 'Round the Baseball World"_.[32] The phrase quickly spread to other
media, and "Shot Heard 'Round the World" soon became the most popular
[epithet](/wiki/Epithet "Epithet") for Thomson's homer.

_[New York Herald Tribune](/wiki/New_York_Herald_Tribune "New York Herald
Tribune")_ sportswriter [Red Smith](/wiki/Red_Smith_\(sportswriter\) "Red
Smith \(sportswriter\)") titled his October 4 column "The Miracle of Coogan's
Bluff", and began it with what has been called "the greatest
[lede](/wiki/Lead_paragraph "Lead paragraph") ever written":

> Now it is done. Now the story ends. And there is no way to tell it. The art
> of fiction is dead. Reality has strangled invention. Only the utterly
> impossible, the inexpressibly fantastic, can ever be plausible again.[33]

The Giants lost the ensuing [World Series](/wiki/1951_World_Series "1951 World
Series") to the Yankees in six games.[34]

Sukeforth resigned his position as bullpen coach in January 1952, after 19
years with the Dodgers. He denied that his role in the final inning of the
Shot game had any bearing on his decision to leave.[35] Some historians have
since speculated otherwise, based on Dressen's post-game reply to why he
brought in Branca: "Sukeforth said he was ready."[36] Sukeforth told a
journalist in 2000—the last year of his life—that "everybody knows the manager
is responsible for decisions." He added, "It didn't matter what anybody said
... Branca was the only one who could come in when that big guy [Newcombe]
couldn't go any further."[37]

Individual recollections of Thomson's home run continued to emerge decades
after the event. In the 1990s, Thomson received a letter from a
[Marine](/wiki/Marines "Marines") who had been stationed in
[Korea](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") in 1951:

    "I was in a bunker in the front line with my buddy listening to the radio. It was contrary to orders, but he was a Giants fanatic. He never made it home and I promised him if I ever got back I'd write and tell you about the happiest moment of his life. It's taken me this long to put my feelings into words. On behalf of my buddy, thanks, Bobby."[38]

In the fall of 2001, surviving members of the 1951 Giants and Dodgers,
including Thomson and Branca, met at [Coogan's Bluff](/wiki/Coogan%27s_Bluff
"Coogan's Bluff"), overlooking the site of the long since demolished ballpark,
to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the game.[39]

Thomson's baseball legacy rests almost completely on the Shot, despite his
other notable accomplishments, such as eight 20-home run seasons and three
[All Star](/wiki/All-star_game "All-star game") selections. "It was the best
thing that ever happened to me", he told a reporter toward the end of his
life. "It may have been the best thing that ever happened to anybody."[40]

###
Controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Controversy")]

In ensuing years, rumors began to circulate that during the second half of the
1951 season, the Giants engaged in the systematic stealing of
[signs](/wiki/Glossary_of_baseball#sign "Glossary of baseball")—the finger
signals transmitted from catcher to pitcher that determine the pitch to be
thrown. The [Associated Press](/wiki/Associated_Press "Associated Press")
reported the rumor in 1962, but with no specifics, and based on an anonymous
source.[41] In 2001, many of the 21 Giants players still alive at the time,
and one surviving coach, told the _[Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/Wall_Street_Journal "Wall Street Journal")_ that beginning on
July 20, the team used a telescope in the Giants clubhouse behind center
field, manned by infielder [Hank Schenz](/wiki/Hank_Schenz "Hank Schenz") and
later by coach [Herman Franks](/wiki/Herman_Franks "Herman Franks"), to steal
the finger signals of opposing catchers. Stolen signs were relayed via a
buzzer wire connected from the clubhouse to telephones in the Giants
[dugout](/wiki/Dugout_\(baseball\) "Dugout \(baseball\)") and
[bullpen](/wiki/Bullpen "Bullpen")—one buzz for a fastball, two for an [off-
speed pitch](/wiki/Off-speed_pitch "Off-speed pitch"). "Every hitter knew what
was coming," said pitcher [Al Gettel](/wiki/Al_Gettel "Al Gettel"). "Made a
big difference."[41] [Joshua Prager](/wiki/Joshua_Prager_\(writer\) "Joshua
Prager \(writer\)"), the author of the _Journal_ article, outlined the
evidence in greater detail in a 2006 book.[42]

Although backup catcher [Sal Yvars](/wiki/Sal_Yvars "Sal Yvars") told Prager
that he relayed Rube Walker's fastball sign to Thomson from the bullpen,
Thomson repeatedly insisted that he was concentrating on the situation, and
did not take the sign.[43] Branca made no public comment at the time. "I made
a decision not to speak about it," he said. "I didn't want to look like I was
crying over spilled milk."[41] Later he told _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , "I didn't want to
diminish a legendary moment in baseball. And even if Bobby knew what was
coming, he had to hit it ... Knowing the pitch doesn't always help."[44] In
another interview, Branca pointed out that luck and circumstance were involved
as well; had the coin toss gone the other way, Thomson's Shot would not have
been a home run at Ebbets Field—nor would the game-winner he hit in the first
playoff game have been a homer at the Polo Grounds.[9]

Whether the telescope-and-buzzer system contributed significantly to the
Giants' late-season 37–7 win streak remains a subject of debate.[45] Prager
notes in his book that sign stealing was not specifically forbidden by MLB
rules at the time and, moral issues aside, "...has been a part of baseball
since its inception".[46] Sign stealing using optical or other mechanical aids
was outlawed by MLB in 1961.[43]

##
Artifacts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Artifacts")]

Some of the artifacts from the historic moment have been preserved. Thomson's
game bat and shoes are the centerpieces of an exhibit dedicated to the Shot at
the [National Baseball Hall of Fame and
Museum](/wiki/National_Baseball_Hall_of_Fame_and_Museum "National Baseball
Hall of Fame and Museum").[47] The exhibit is one of the Hall's most popular
attractions, according to curators.[48]

Thomson's game jersey is most likely in the collection of Dan Scheinman, a
collector who owns a small minority stake in the Giants. In 2005, he bought
two 1951 jerseys—one home and one road—from Thomson, who told him that he had
worn them in the World Series, but could not remember whether he had worn the
home jersey for the Shot game. Scheinman has said that he is "about 90
percent" confident that the home jersey is indeed the one Thomson was wearing
when he hit the Shot: The Giants almost certainly wore the same uniforms for
the Series—which began the day after the Shot game—that they used during the
second half of the season (as did the Yankees), and Scheinman's jersey
displays distinct puckering around the numbers, probably as a result of steam
pressing, that is visible in photos of Thomson taken during and immediately
after the Shot game. According to a professional textile conservator, such
puckering cannot be mimicked or reproduced, and would not repeat itself in
exactly the same pattern on a different jersey.[48]

The location of the ball is unknown. Documentary filmmaker and author Brian
Biegel attempted unsuccessfully to authenticate a vintage baseball,
autographed by several 1951 Giants, that his father had purchased at a thrift
store for four dollars, and believed to be Thomson's home run ball. He
chronicled the project in his 2011 book _Miracle Ball_ , followed by a
documentary film of the same name.[47]

##
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Shot_Heard_%27Round_the_World_\(baseball\)&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Legacy")]

The Shot game placed second on [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN")'s _SportsCentury_
ranking of the Ten Greatest Games of the 20th Century, behind the [1958 NFL
Championship Game](/wiki/1958_NFL_Championship_Game "1958 NFL Championship
Game").[49] _[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports
Illustrated")_ ranked Thomson's home run fifteenth on its list of the 100
Greatest Moments in Sports History.[50]
